awd_abstract_narration:
RAISE-EQuIP:Quantum Mux/Demux: The Quantum Optical Frequency Comb as a Scalable Quantum Encoding Resource
 
Quantum information and quantum computing are emerging fields that have the potential to revolutionize various areas in science and technology. As first foreseen by Richard Feynman, quantum computers will enable calculations at currently unattainable scales and will bring unprecedented advances over classical computers. Examples include calculations of large biological molecules for revolutionary drug discovery, solving complex quantum mechanical systems, and factoring integers at a speed exponentially faster than classical computer to defeat current standard encryption methods. Quantum information is also fundamentally distinct from classical information. It cannot be cloned or hacked and therefore brings new power for cryptography, such as the method of quantum key distribution to create secure communications channels. The realization of practical systems capable of quantum computing and information is an extraordinary difficult task but will have profound impacts on national security and our society. To date, two primary challenges have been identified in making quantum technology a reality: achieving scalability and circumventing decoherence. At this juncture, many proof-of principle results have been experimentally demonstrated to address either decoherence (trapped-ion, superconducting, and cold atom qubits), or the scalability problem (field qumodes), but both requirements have not been met simultaneously yet. This project will address both of these challenges by a joint interdisciplinary effort between the Electrical and Computer Engineering and the Physics Departments at University of Virginia by ways of scalable integrated quantum photonics.

The aim of this project is to marry scalable integrated photonics with quantum information and quantum computation over continuous variables in order to encode quantum information over the quantum optical frequency comb (QOFC). Such technology will empower unconditional quantum protocols such as quantum communication, quantum entanglement distillation, and quantum simulation. With NSF support, the quantum optics group at the University of Virginia has been pioneering the implementation of QOFC in optical parametric oscillator and has achieved record-levels of multipartite entanglements (60 qumodes). Integrated microresonator-based optical frequency combs, heterogeneous photonic integration and near unity quantum efficiency photodiodes have been in the focus of research in the micro-photonics, optoelectronic and photonics device groups at UVA for many years. The project aims to combine these efforts and create a unique integrated device on a chip with multimode quantum emitter, qumodes processing and detection. Such a realization enables numerous quantum applications on a chip, including massively scalable cluster entanglement, scalable deterministic quantum processing, quantum secret sharing over QOFC, and quantum mode sorting.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The NSF ECCS-1842641 grant “RAISE-EQuIP: Quantum mux/demux: the quantum optical frequency comb as a scalable quantum encoding resource” supported the collaborative research of 4 experimental groups at the University of Virginia: Prof. Olivier Pfister in the Physics Department and Profs. Andreas Beling, Joe Campbell, and Xu Yi in the Charles L. Brown Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering. This collaborative research effort was a parallel approach to realizing the common goal of an integrated photonic platform suitable to build a quantum computer of sufficient size to offer nontrivial computing power. This effort aimed at translating Pfister’s advances from free-space quantum optics to on-chip quantum photonics. This required developing both on-chip quantum light sources and on-chip high-performance photodetection of fields and of photons. 

Under this award, the Yi group demonstrated quantum sources of light emitting entangled frequency combs, i.e., optical fields of evenly spaced frequencies and presenting pairwise quantum correlations. These quantum fields were entangled in pairs, thereby providing a resource for quantum teleportation, as well as the basic building block for a measurement-based quantum computer (as demonstrated earlier by the Pfister group). These demonstrations took place on two different microresonators, a silica disk (in collaboration with the Pfister group) and a silicon nitride ring, and respectively featured an on-chip record 40 and 70 entangled qumodes.

In the aforementioned results, the characterization of the quantum correlations was limited by the losses incurred when coupling the light out of the chip into free-space detectors. The Beling group demonstrated on-chip photodiodes at the design wavelength of 1550 nm, with a high quantum efficiency, low dark current, and very high bandwidth. A balanced detector also achieved a 40 dB common-mode rejection ratio at 20 GHz, all on waveguide. 

The Campbell group has continued their decades-long pioneering of semiconductor photodetectors, focusing under this award on field-resolved (e.g. homodyne) and photon-number-resolved (PNR) photodetection for photonic quantum computing. One main result is the demonstration of near-ideal (100%) quantum efficiency at 1550 nm in a PIN diode, which is key to field-resolved measurements. For PNR measurements, the Beling and Pfister groups have shown under this award that single-photon avalanche photodiodes (SPAD) can be used to form a segmented photodetector and gain high-performance PNR capability. While the segmented architecture removes all constraints on SPAD quantum efficiency—a truly remarkable result—the SPADs must nonetheless exhibit 100% correlation between its avalanche signals and the detected photons. This means that the SPAD must perform at unity breakdown probability and zero afterpulsing. Using a novel photodiode material (AlInAsSb), the Campbell group demonstrated high breakdown probability. Moreover, the Campbell group demonstrated a new approach to APD quenching—to limit afterpulsing from trapped avalanche carriers, in the absence of photons—by using a variable-resistor circuit. These results pave the way to room-temperature PNR detection, which would be a game changer for photonic quantum computing: all current PNR detectors (transition edge sensors, superconducting nanowire single-photon detectors) are superconducting and therefore cryogenic ones, which greatly impacts the designs and budgets of photonic quantum computing .

The Pfister group continued investigating fundamental table-top quantum optics toward its translation into on-chip implementations, focusing on the particle nature of light via photon-number-resolving detection. Main results, in addition to collaborative work mentioned above, include a new method for generating large-scale qumodes cluster (entangled) states using phase modulation of the frequency comb. 

Four patent applications were generated from the collaborative work done under this grant, which successfully demonstrated a number of the required building blocks necessary to build a high-quality photonic quantum computer. 

This paved the way for the founding by all 4 co-PIs of quantum computing startup QC82, Inc., in 2020. QC82’s goal is to develop the currently missing quantum hardware in order to build the first scalable, fault tolerant, photonic quantum computer. QC82 recently completed a successful $3M seed funding round and is one of only 3 companies in the DARPA US2QC program.
